sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono: Short bowel syndrome, dependant on parenteral support: 0.05 mg/kg SUBQ once daily

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono:
• renal impairment: moderate to severe (CrCl less than 50 mL/min) or ESRD; reduce dose by 50%
  • hepatic impairment: mild to moderate (Child-Pugh grade B) no dose adjustment necessary
  • geriatric patients: no dose adjustment necessary

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Short bowel syndrome, dependant on parenteral support

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• biliary tract and gallbladder disease (cholecystitis, cholangitis, cholelithiasis) has been reported; monitoring recommended; reassess need for continued treatment with clinically meaningful changes
  • colorectal polyps have been reported; monitoring recommended; if polyps occur, adhere to follow-up guidelines; if colorectal cancer occurs, discontinue use
  • concomitant oral medications; increased absorption may occur; use caution with drugs that have a narrow therapeutic index or require titration (eg, benzodiazepines, psychotropic agents)
  • fluid and electrolyte imbalances have been reported on discontinuation
  • fluid overload, including congestive heart failure, has been reported; adjust parenteral support and reassess need for continued treatment if symptoms occur, especially with underlying cardiovascular disease or if significant cardiac deterioration develops
  • gastrointestinal (GI) malignancy (GI tract, hepatobiliary, pancreatic), active; discontinue use
  • hyperplastic changes, including neoplasia, may occur; among patients at increased risk for malignancy and in patients with active nongastrointestinal malignancy, use only if benefits outweigh risks
  • intestinal or stomal obstruction has been reported; temporarily discontinue use if occurs; upon resolution, therapy may be resumed if clinically indicated
  • pancreatic disease (pancreatitis) has been reported; monitoring recommended; reassess need for continued treatment if clinically meaningful changes occur
  • renal impairment, moderate or severe (CrCl less than 50 mL/min) or end-stage renal disease; dosage adjustment required
  • small bowel neoplasia may occur; monitoring recommended; remove benign neoplasm if occurs; discontinue use if small bowel cancer occurs
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site reaction (12% to 21.8%)
  • Endocrine metabolic:Hypervolemia (11.7%)
  • Gastrointestinal:Abdominal distension (14.8% to 19.5%), Abdominal pain (31.3% to 37.7%), Complication of external stoma of gastrointestinal tract (41.9%), Nausea (18.8% to 24.7%), Vomiting (11.7%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (16.3%)
  • Respiratory:Upper respiratory infection (11.9% to 26%)
Serious
  • Gastrointestinal:Bowel obstruction (3.9% to 9.4%), Cholecystitis, Pancreatitis, Polyp, Colorectal
  • Respiratory:Lung cancer
  • Other:Lung cancer, Metastatic adenocarcinoma of unknown origin

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Teduglutide is a 33 amino acid glucagon-like peptide-2 (GLP-2) analog manufactured using recombinant DNA technology. Naturally occurring human GLP-2 is a peptide secreted by L-cells of the distal intestine. GLP-2 increases intestinal and portal blood flow, and inhibits gastric acid secretion. Teduglutide binds to GLP-2 receptors in the intestinal subpopulations of enteroendocrine cells, subepithelial myofibroblasts, and enteric neurons of the submucosal and myenteric plexus. Activation of GLP-2 receptors leads to local release of insulin-like growth factor, nitric oxide, and keratinocyte growth factor. Administration of teduglutide improves intestinal absorption in patients with short bowel syndrome who are dependent on parenteral support.

sub.title: Absorption
sub.mono:
• Tmax, subQ; 3 to 5 hours
  • Tmax, subQ; renal impairment: 4 to 4.5 hours
  • Bioavailability, subQ: 88%

sub.title: Metabolism
sub.mono: small peptides and amino acids: unknown

sub.title: Excretion
sub.mono:
• Renal clearance: extensive
  • Total body clearance: 123 mL/hr/kg
  • Total body clearance, renal impairment: decreased; 4.83 L/hr (moderate), 6.21 L/hr (severe); 7.52 L/hr (ESRD)

sub.title: Elimination Half Life
sub.mono:
• Healthy subjects, 2 hours to 6 hours
  • Short bowel syndrome, 1.3 hours

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    do not administer by IV or IM injection
  • Subcutaneous
    • reconstitute with 0.5 mL of sterile water for injection (provided in prefilled syringe) and let stand for 30 seconds
    • gently roll vial for 15 seconds and then let stand for about 2 minutes; do not shake
    • if undissolved powder is visible, gently roll vial again; do not use product if it remains undissolved after second attempt
    • administer within 3 hours of reconstitution; discard unused portion
    • alternate injection sites (eg, arms, thighs, and quadrants of the abdomen)

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• reduction in weekly parenteral nutrition (PN) or IV support may indicate efficacy
  • bilirubin, alkaline phosphatase, lipase and amylase; within 6 months of initiating therapy, and at least every 6 months while on therapy, or more frequently if required.
  • electrolyte status; upon discontinuation of treatment.
  • colonoscopy or alternative imaging of the entire colon with removal of polyps; within 6 months of initiating treatment, after 1 years of treatment, then at least every 5 years if no polyp is found, or per current polyp followup guidelines if a polyp is found
  • fluid status; upon discontinuation of treatment.
  • signs and symptoms of small bowel neoplasms
  • gallbladder and/or biliary tract imaging if clinical meaningful changes in bilirubin and/or alkaline phosphatase levels are seen
  • pancreatic imaging if clinically meaningful changes in lipase and/or amylase are seen

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause abdominal pain, injection site reactions, swelling of stoma, nausea, headaches, abdominal distension, upper respiratory tract infections, or vomiting.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of intestinal obstruction.
  • Advise patient to report signs/symptoms of cholecystitis, cholangitis, cholelithiasis, or pancreatic disease to a healthcare professional.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of fluid overload or cardiac decompensation.
  • Advise patient to report a severe reaction, including severe rash, to a healthcare professional.
  • Teach patient proper injection technique and placement of injections.
  • Advise patient to rotate injection sites.
  • Advise patient there are multiple significant drug-drug interactions for this drug. Consult healthcare professional prior to new drug use (including over-the-counter and herbal drugs).
  • Instruct patient to take a missed dose as soon as possible on the day the dose is missed, but if next scheduled dose is the same day, skip the missed dose. Patient should not take 2 doses on the same day.
